publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A search is presented for flavour-changing neutral-current interactions involving the top quark, the Higgs boson and an up-type quark (<jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$q=u,c$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>q</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mo>=</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mi>u</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mo>,</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mi>c</mml:mi>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula>) with the ATLAS detector at the Large Hadron Collider. The analysis considers leptonic decays of the top quark along with Higgs boson decays into two <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$W$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mi>W</mml:mi>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> bosons, two <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$Z$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> bosons or a <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$\tau ^{+}\tau ^{-}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:msup>
                      <mml:mi>τ</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>+</mml:mo>
                    </mml:msup>
                    <mml:msup>
                      <mml:mi>τ</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
                    </mml:msup>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> pair. It focuses on final states containing either two leptons (electrons or muons) of the same charge or three leptons. The considered processes are <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$t\bar{t}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mover>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                      </mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mo>¯</mml:mo>
                      </mml:mrow>
                    </mml:mover>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> and <jats:italic>Ht</jats:italic> production. For the <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$t\bar{t}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mover>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                      </mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mo>¯</mml:mo>
                      </mml:mrow>
                    </mml:mover>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> production, one top quark decays via <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$t\rightarrow Hq$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mo>→</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mi>H</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mi>q</mml:mi>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula>. The proton–proton collision data set analysed amounts to <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$({140}\,{\hbox {fb}^{-1}})$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mn>140</mml:mn>
                    <mml:mspace/>
                    <mml:msup>
                      <mml:mtext>fb</mml:mtext>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
                        <mml:mn>1</mml:mn>
                      </mml:mrow>
                    </mml:msup>
                    <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> at <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$(\sqrt{s}={13}\,\hbox {TeV})$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                    <mml:msqrt>
                      <mml:mi>s</mml:mi>
                    </mml:msqrt>
                    <mml:mo>=</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mn>13</mml:mn>
                    <mml:mspace/>
                    <mml:mtext>TeV</mml:mtext>
                    <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula>. No significant excess beyond Standard Model expectations is observed and upper limits are set on the <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$t\rightarrow Hq$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mo>→</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mi>H</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mi>q</mml:mi>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> branching ratios at 95 % confidence level, amounting to observed (expected) limits of <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$\mathcal {B}(t\rightarrow Hu)<2.8\,(3.0) \times 10^{-4}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>B</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>→</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mi>H</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mi>u</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                    </mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo><</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mn>2.8</mml:mn>
                    <mml:mspace/>
                    <mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mn>3.0</mml:mn>
                      <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                    </mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo>×</mml:mo>
                    <mml:msup>
                      <mml:mn>10</mml:mn>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
                        <mml:mn>4</mml:mn>
                      </mml:mrow>
                    </mml:msup>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> and <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$\mathcal {B}(t\rightarrow Hc)<3.3\,(3.8) \times 10^{-4}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>B</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>→</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mi>H</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mi>c</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                    </mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo><</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mn>3.3</mml:mn>
                    <mml:mspace/>
                    <mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mn>3.8</mml:mn>
                      <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                    </mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo>×</mml:mo>
                    <mml:msup>
                      <mml:mn>10</mml:mn>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
                        <mml:mn>4</mml:mn>
                      </mml:mrow>
                    </mml:msup>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula>. Combining this search with other searches for <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$tHq$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>tHq</mml:mi>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> flavour-changing neutral-current interactions previously conducted by ATLAS, considering <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$H\rightarrow b\bar{b}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>H</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mo>→</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mi>b</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mover>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mi>b</mml:mi>
                      </mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mo>¯</mml:mo>
                      </mml:mrow>
                    </mml:mover>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> and <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$H\rightarrow \gamma \gamma $$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>H</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mo>→</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mi>γ</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mi>γ</mml:mi>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> decays, as well as <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$H\rightarrow \tau ^{+}\tau ^{-}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>H</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mo>→</mml:mo>
                    <mml:msup>
                      <mml:mi>τ</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>+</mml:mo>
                    </mml:msup>
                    <mml:msup>
                      <mml:mi>τ</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
                    </mml:msup>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> decays with one or two hadronically decaying <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$\tau $$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mi>τ</mml:mi>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula>-leptons, yields observed (expected) upper limits on the branching ratios of <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$\mathcal {B}(t\rightarrow Hu)<2.6\,(1.8) \times 10^{-4}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>B</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>→</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mi>H</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mi>u</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                    </mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo><</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mn>2.6</mml:mn>
                    <mml:mspace/>
                    <mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mn>1.8</mml:mn>
                      <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                    </mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo>×</mml:mo>
                    <mml:msup>
                      <mml:mn>10</mml:mn>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
                        <mml:mn>4</mml:mn>
                      </mml:mrow>
                    </mml:msup>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula> and <jats:inline-formula><jats:alternatives><jats:tex-math>$$\mathcal {B}(t\rightarrow Hc)<3.4\,(2.3) \times 10^{-4}$$</jats:tex-math><mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">
                  <mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mi>B</mml:mi>
                    <mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mi>t</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>→</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mi>H</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mi>c</mml:mi>
                      <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                    </mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo><</mml:mo>
                    <mml:mn>3.4</mml:mn>
                    <mml:mspace/>
                    <mml:mrow>
                      <mml:mo>(</mml:mo>
                      <mml:mn>2.3</mml:mn>
                      <mml:mo>)</mml:mo>
                    </mml:mrow>
                    <mml:mo>×</mml:mo>
                    <mml:msup>
                      <mml:mn>10</mml:mn>
                      <mml:mrow>
                        <mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
                        <mml:mn>4</mml:mn>
                      </mml:mrow>
                    </mml:msup>
                  </mml:mrow>
                </mml:math></jats:alternatives></jats:inline-formula>.</jats:p>
title: Search for flavour-changing neutral-current couplings between the top quark and the Higgs boson in multi-lepton final states in 13 TeV pp collisions with the ATLAS detector

reference.unstructured: ATLAS Collaboration, Observation of a new particle in the search for the Standard Model Higgs boson with the ATLAS detector at the LHC. Phys. Lett. B 716, 1 (2012). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.physletb.2012.08.020. arXiv:1207.7214 [hep-ex]

CMS Collaboration, Observation of a new boson at a mass of 125 GeV with the CMS experiment at the LHC. Phys. Lett. B 716, 30 (2012). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.physletb.2012.08.021. arXiv:1207.7235 [hep-ex]

ATLAS Collaboration, A detailed map of Higgs boson interactions by the ATLAS experiment ten years after the discovery. Nature 607, 52 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-022-04893-w. arXiv:2207.00092 [hep-ex] [Erratum: Nature 612 (2022) E24. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-022-05581-5]

CMS Collaboration, A portrait of the Higgs boson by the CMS experiment ten years after the discovery. Nature 607, 60 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-022-04892-x. arXiv:2207.00043 [hep-ex] [Erratum: Nature 623 (2023) E4. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-023-06164-8]

D. de Florian et al., Handbook of LHC Higgs Cross Sections: 4. Deciphering the Nature of the Higgs Sector (2017). https://doi.org/10.23731/CYRM-2017-002. arXiv:1610.07922 [hep-ph]

ATLAS Collaboration, Search for top-quark decays $$t \rightarrow Hq$$ with $$36\,\text{fb}^{-1}$$ of $$pp$$ collision data at $$\sqrt{s} = 13\,\text{ TeV }$$ with the ATLAS detector. JHEP 05, 123 (2019). https://doi.org/10.1007/JHEP05(2019)123. arXiv:1812.11568 [hep-ex]

ATLAS Collaboration, Search for top quark decays $$t\rightarrow qH$$, with $$H\rightarrow \gamma \gamma $$, in $$\sqrt{s} = 13\,\text{ TeV }$$$$pp$$ collisions using the ATLAS detector. JHEP 10, 129 (2017). https://doi.org/10.1007/JHEP10(2017)129. arXiv:1707.01404 [hep-ex]

ATLAS Collaboration, Search for flavor-changing neutral currents in top quark decays $$t \rightarrow Hc$$ and $$t \rightarrow Hu$$ in multilepton final states in proton–proton collisions at $$\sqrt{s} = 13\,\text{ TeV }$$ with the ATLAS detector. ATLAS Collaboration, Search for flavour-changing neutral current interactions of the top quark and the Higgs boson in events with a pair of $$\tau $$-leptons in $$pp$$ collisions at $$\sqrt{s} = 13\,\text{ TeV }$$ with the ATLAS detector. JHEP 06, 155 (2023). https://doi.org/10.1007/JHEP06(2023)155. arXiv:2208.11415 [hep-ex]

ATLAS Collaboration, Search for a new scalar resonance in flavour-changing neutral-current top-quark decays $$t \rightarrow qX\ (q=u,c$$), with $$X\rightarrow b\bar{b}$$, in proton–proton collisions at $$\sqrt{s} = 13\,\text{ TeV }$$ with the ATLAS detector. JHEP 07, 199 (2023). https://doi.org/10.1007/JHEP07(2023)199. arXiv:2301.03902 [hep-ex]

reference.author: CMS Collaboration
reference.unstructured: C.M.S.
